Legal_Issue: Whether blacklisting constitutes persecution under the Convention refugee status
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant faced difficulties in employment and education due to blacklisting by Chinese authorities following involvement in student uprisings
Decision_Outcome: Board dismissed claim as mere discrimination; Federal Court quashed decision
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board's decision
Court_Ruling: Federal Court allowed judicial review, quashed Board's decision, referred back for redetermination
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on political opinion or association with student uprisings
Legal_Standard: Persecution involves serious restrictions on rights such as livelihood, religion, or education
Assessment_Factor: Impact of blacklisting on livelihood, education, and employment opportunities
Applicable_Legislation: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of administrative decision by Immigration and Refugee Board
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on legal interpretation and evidentiary sufficiency
Evidence_Used: Evidence of blacklisting and its effects on employment and education
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to past political activities
Evidence_Assessed: Sufficiency of evidence linking blacklisting to adverse impacts
Governing_Rule: Persecution requires more than discrimination unless it leads to substantially prejudicial consequences
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remitted for redetermination
Harm_Assessment: Restrictions on livelihood and educational opportunities due to state-imposed blacklisting
Cause_Description: Alleged persecution by Chinese authorities after participation in student uprisings
Evidence_Handling: Federal Court found Board failed to properly assess impact of blacklisting
Legal_Provision_Violated: None directly violated; issue of interpretation of refugee eligibility under IRPA
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient reasoning by Board in downplaying severity of blacklisting
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and Section 97 of IRPA, Article 1A(2) of the Refugee Convention
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction to conduct judicial review of IRB decisions
Evidence_Assessment: Blacklisting must be assessed for its real-world consequences on fundamental rights
Decision_Rationale: Denial of livelihood through official blacklisting may amount to persecution
Decision_Making_Body: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to substantiate why blacklisting did not lead to persecutory harm
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether discriminatory treatment rises to level of persecution
